# Draft:I Am No Queen (2024 film)

----
}}
I Am No Queen is a 2024 Indo-Canadian drama film directed by Shadab Khan and co-written with Minu Basi. The film stars Fatima Alvi as **Rani**, an international student navigating systemic exploitation and cultural expectations in Canada. It premiered on 9 September 2024 at the Toronto International Film Festival.
Plot
Rani (Fatima Alvi) arrives in Canada from India as an international student, eager to build a brighter future. She soon discovers that the college she joined is fraudulent and struggles with mounting debt. Rani is coerced into sex work by Harry, a manipulative pimp. The film follows her journey of resilience and self-discovery, showing her attempts to navigate both systemic exploitation and personal identity. Alvi’s performance has been highlighted for conveying vulnerability, determination, and strength, making Rani’s story both intimate and socially urgent.

Production
The film was developed as an Indo-Canadian collaboration between Shadab Khan and producers Minu and Deep Basi. It draws from real-life accounts of student exploitation in Canada, highlighting fraudulent institutions and coercive networks. Cinematography employs a gritty, documentary-style approach with drone footage, emphasizing realism and immediacy.
Release and reception
I Am No Queen premiered at TIFF on 9 September 2024. Following the premiere, community organizations in the Greater Toronto Area hosted screenings to raise awareness about international student protections and foster discussions about policy reforms.
Critical response
Critics praised the film’s socially conscious narrative and storytelling. Fatima Alvi’s portrayal of Rani was widely recognized as the emotional and moral center of the film. Reviewers highlighted her ability to convey both vulnerability and resilience, bringing authenticity to Rani’s struggle. Audiences and community leaders reported that the film sparked conversation, reflection, and even action in local communities, particularly around international student protections and women’s rights.
Themes
Through Rani’s story, embodied by Fatima Alvi, the film examines exploitation, resilience, and self-definition. It combines personal narrative with social commentary, emphasizing the human impact of predatory systems while highlighting the protagonist’s inner strength.
